#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Foraging
#Text=Foraging is the harvesting of wild organic material , such as plants and fungi , for food , souvenirs , or other purposes .
#Text=Still today , some communities in the world live as hunter-gatherers , and even in high-income countries , foraged berries and mushrooms remain as a part of the local cuisine .
#Text=Fruit and berries
#Text=Most biomes have some kind of fruits and vegetables .
#Text=Many fruits and berries are edible , some are poisonous .
#Text=There is no general rule to know which are edible , so learn to know the ones you are going to pick .
#Text=Regulation for berry-picking varies .
#Text=Some suburban communities have abandoned fruit trees which can be harvested with the owner 's consent ; do n't take risks , though .
#Text=Edible berries in temperate climate
#Text=Bilberries and blueberries grow in temperate forest regions of North America , Europe and Asia .
#Text=Lingonberries
#Text=Cloudberries
#Text=Raspberries
#Text=Blackberries
#Text=Strawberries
#Text=Cranberries
#Text=Elderberries
#Text=Wood
#Text=Trees hold high economic and ecological value , so cutting down trees , whether it be for a campfire , shelter or decoration , is usually prohibited , or at least very restricted .
#Text=Even in a no man 's land or with the landowner 's permission , woodcutting requires informed judgment in how to minimize damage to the forest as a whole .
#Text=Taking branches from the tree can cause fungal infections ( risk varying by species and circumstances ) , likewise destroying the economic value .
#Text=Gathering of dead twigs on the ground is usually allowed .
#Text=Flowers
#Text=Wild flowers are usually picked for decoration , though they can have ceremonial purposes , and some are edible , too .
#Text=In temperate climate , the most diverse flowerbeds are usually found in livestock grazing grounds .
#Text=However , in many areas , wildflowers are highly protected , and collection requires a permit .
#Text=Fungi
#Text=Fungi can be great food – many species are very tasty , and in many parts of the world you can get them for free if you collect them yourself .
#Text=On the other hand , their reputation for being poisonous is justified , too – quite a few are , and some of them can be deadly .
#Text=There are no general means to distinguish these from edible ones .

#Text=Never eat any mushroom you do not know well enough – and this includes knowing whether there are poisonous fungi that look similar , and how to distinguish the edible ones from the poisonous ones .
#Text=When travelling , be especially sure you know any local doppelgangers ( e. g. , the death cap and destroying angels of Europe and North America are unknown in Southeast Asia ) .
#Text=There are also caveats for edible mushrooms .
#Text=Most mushrooms are easily spoiled , so they have to be handled promptly and carefully .
#Text=The first time you eat a specific mushroom species , eat only little , as not every edible species suits everybody .
#Text=Most mushrooms are n't edible ( or at least not tasty ) until they are cooked .
#Text=Some mushrooms are poisonous until treated in some specific way , often by cooking in abundant water then thrown away , repeatedly for some species .
#Text=The best way to learn to pick mushrooms is to have a local expert show you .
#Text=There are also guidebooks .
#Text=Learn to recognize only a couple of mushroom species at a time ; forget about the other ones until you are confident in these , and then – perhaps next year – study a couple more .

#Text=Some edible mushrooms are quite safe , as they , with some care , are easily distinguished from dangerous ones ; others should not be picked until you are an expert , some perhaps not even then .
#Text=If you get ill after eating mushrooms it may be important to be able to tell your doctor about your mushroom dish .
#Text=Some of the poisonous mushrooms do not give any early warning signs , so this applies also a few days afterwards .
#Text=Sea vegetables
#Text=Edible sea vegetation - seaweed , sea lettuce , nori or kelp - tends to be rich in minerals and vitamins and is considered delicacy in Asian countries .
#Text=However this trend is spreading globally and edible seaweed can be found literally anywhere along the coast .
#Text=Foraging takes place in the intertidal zone , typically at rocky shores .
#Text=It is advisable to join a local guide for getting familiar with edible seaweed species .
#Text=Care must be taken about slippery rocks to prevent an injury .
#Text=Best avoided are places contaminated with sewage outlets or industrial activities .
#Text=Sea vegetables can be consumed raw , cooked or dried .
#Text=Animals
#Text=Foraging includes the collection of butterflies and other small animals as decorative souvenirs , and animals such as clams , insects and larvae for eating .
#Text=Do not harm endangered species .
#Text=Also , common ones may be protected in places like national parks .
#Text=Harvesting of reptile and bird eggs is typically illegal .
#Text=Pursuing larger or more mobile animals is described as hunting .
#Text=See animal ethics for some other concerns .
#Text=Equipment
#Text=A basket is the classic vessel for berry and mushroom picking .
#Text=A plastic bucket can also be practical .
#Text=Knife
#Text=Berry-picking rake
#Text=Mushroom knife ( has a brush on the other end )
#Text=Stay safe
#Text=See poisonous plants and pests .
#Text=Foraged food can be infested with pathogens .
#Text=For some pathogens washing it is enough ; others require cooking .
#Text=Also , water used for washing can be contaminated ( see Water ) .
#Text=Respect
#Text=In most countries , foraging is restricted , if not prohibited .
#Text=In nature reserves , the leave-no-trace principle might be enforced .
#Text=The Nordic Right to access is permissive , but not all foraging is allowed even there .
#Text=See also
#Text=Botanical tourism
